quote: You know, Morn -- there's nothing    quite as invigorating as breakfast    in a bar. Where else can you get    raw slug livers first thing in the    morning?
What's this?
What do you mean, "what's this?"    It's puree of beetle.
I didn't order it.
Of course you "didn't order it" --    you don't need to order it. You    have it after work every morning.
Well, I'm not having it this    morning. I'd like two eggs, over    easy with three strips of bacon    and a side of corned beef hash.
What kind of breakfast is that?
It's Chief O'Brien's breakfast of    choice.
That's the problem with working    alongside Hew-mons, you pick up    their disgusting habits. Bacon.    Corned beef hash...        What's next? Orange juice and    coffee?
That might be nice.
I don't understand it. You gave    up a perfectly good job with me to    work on the station's waste    extraction system.
A good waste extraction system is    important. Imagine where we'd be    without one.
Of course it's important -- but my    point is, you're not getting the    choice assignments. O'Brien's got    you on the night shift doing all    the work no one else wants to do.
(doesn't see the     problem)    I like my work.
You like standing all night long,    knee-deep in waste, fixing some    broken flow regulator? When you    could be here --
-- staring at half-naked dabo   girls?

I have a good job. I'm proud of    the work I do.        And I know that one day, Chief    O'Brien will recognize my efforts    and reward me with a position of    respect and responsibility. And   why?        Because that's just the way things    are... in Engineering.
I'm sorry I brought it up.
They looked fine last night.
They don't look so fine now.
I can't understand it... I've been    following Keiko's instructions to    the letter...
They were dry as a bone when I    came by for you yesterday. I gave    them water, but I guess it wasn't    enough.
You watered them?
These are Idran hybrids. Too much    water rots their roots.
Oh.
Mommy's going to be mad.
I can't believe it. Keiko's been    gone for five days and we've    killed her plants.
She'll understand, won't she?    After all, they're just plants.
They're not "just plants" -    they're her bonsai trees.
She's nurtured them and cared for    them, carefully sculpted their    growth for... months... years.
You're in trouble.
Molly, honey, listen... why don't    we both go to the airlock and    welcome Mommy back together. Then    after we've hugged and kissed her,    you can explain what happened.
Not me.
Don't look at me.
You killed her plants.
We killed them.
But I think you're overreacting    to the situation. Keiko will    forgive you. After all, today's    your birthday, right?
So far, it's one I'd like to    forget.
And Keiko's been away on Bajor --    she's missed you. Bring her a    gift -- what's her favorite    chocolate?
Tellurian mint truffles. But I    still think you should be there    with me.

You don't need me. You know how    to handle your own wife -- I've    seen you do it a thousand times.    Just say you're sorry and take    full responsibility. You'll be    fine.        Besides, I'll be in surgery --    operating.
On who?
I'll find somebody.
It was Julian. He overwatered    them. He was trying to be helpful --   but you know how he is, he doesn't    always know what he's doing.
I'm sorry, sweetheart. We'll get    new ones.
Forget it, Miles. They're just    plants.
Exactly.
It's not as if something happened   to Molly or the baby.
Right. Everyone's just fine. No    problems at all.
Good. What about Kira -    is she back?
No, she's still with Shaakar    traveling around Dahkur Province.    I thought you were going to visit    them.
I didn't have a chance.
Fine. And now it's time for me to    tell you something.
I'm not Keiko.
Then who are you?
Listen carefully, Miles. I've    taken possession of your wife's    body and I will hold it hostage    until you've done everything I    tell you to do -- accurately, and    without question.
Everything?
If you don't do precisely what I    ask, I'll kill your wife.
Maybe there's been an outbreak of    Rudellian brain fever on Bajor.    Let's go down and see Julian, so    he can...
I see you're going to need a    demonstration of my sincerity.
No!
No, Miles. You're not telling    anyone. If you do, I'll stop her    heart... forever.
If you're really in control of my    wife's body, let me speak to her.
She can "hear" whatever you want    to say.
That's not good enough. I want to    talk to her -- I want her to talk    to me.
You're in no position to make any    demands, Miles.
Strange, these corporeal bodies of    yours. So fragile. Burst a tiny   blood vessel in the brain and    every memory, every passionate    emotion...        Gone forever.
You shouldn't let me eat all of    these by myself.
I'm not hungry.
Why don't you just tell me what    ou want me to do so we can get    this over with.
Very well...
But I want to make one thing clear --   I won't do anything that'll    jeopardize this station or the    people on it.
Don't worry, Miles. All I want    you to do is reconfigure some of    the communication and sensor   relays on the station.
What for?
I can't tell you that.
You're going to have to be    patient. The communication and    sensor relays are distributed    throughout the entire station.
You know your wife well, Miles.    But she knows you even better.

You're playing for time so you can    get to your friends. Dax, Julian,   Captain Sisko -- I know they'll    all want to help you.         The captain may even allow you to    do what I'm asking -- at least    until someone can figure a way to    "trap me" in some kind of stasis    field or some other clever device    you're already dreaming up.

And you know what? It might work.    You might be able to stop me.    (then cold and hard as    steel)   But I promise you one thing -- if   you do, Keiko will die. All I   need is a split second to cause a   massive brain hemorrhage...       ... and she's gone.
I realize this is a difficult    adjustment for you to make, but we    don't have a lot of time.
What do you want me to do?
How long is this going to take?
Two hours to make the    modifications and five or six    hours to cover my tracks.        If I don't -- my crew will catch    on to what I'm doing before you    can say isolinear injunction.
I'm glad to see some of your good    humor returning.
This doesn't need to be an    unpleasant experience.
In order to keep the polarity    shift invisible to security    checks, I'll have to tap into the    optronic integrator on Level Five.
You're the engineer.
What is it, Miles? What do you    want to ask me?        You always tighten your brow just    a tiny bit when you're about to    ask a question -- it's something    only a wife would notice.
Why Keiko? Why take control of    her -- and not me? I'm the one    who knows how to do the work.    It'd be more efficient --
Come in.
Hope I'm not interrupting...
You are. We're busy.
Miles! Don't be rude.
Did you tell her?
Bajoran spiny basil... how    thoughtful!
It's the least I can do after...
It's all right, Julian. I forgive    you.        Now, you are going to make it to    the party tonight, aren't you?
I'll be here.        I guess it's not a surprise    anymore.
I can't believe I did that.        I arranged a birthday dinner for    you tonight. But I wanted it to    be a surprise.
It's okay.        I don't like surprises.
I better go. I left a patient on    the operating table.        I'll see you later.
Thanks, Julian. This was sweet.
A party? Tonight?
It is your birthday.
We can't have all those people    here. We'll have to cancel it.
And raise suspicions? It's better    if the dinner goes on as planned.        Besides, your wife went through a    lot of trouble to arrange it.
You'd better get to work -- you    don't want to be late for your    shift briefing and I've got a lot    of cooking to do.
Diagnostic and Repair Technician,   Junior Grade Rom reporting.
Right. You're Duarte's   replacement.  Have a seat.
I'm on the swing shift?
For a day or two.
What's the matter with Duarte?
Sick as a vole.
Is this where Duarte sits?
(looking at their coffee     mugs)   So, what are you drinking?
Raktajino.
Great. Is that what we drink on   the swing shift?
You can drink anything you want.
I'll have a raktajino.
It's not like this on the night   shift.
We don't drink raktajino...       We don't really drink anything.
Fascinating.
(glancing over at the     door)   Wonder what's keeping the chief --   he's never late for a briefing.
That's married life for you. Just    as I'm walking out the door -- my    wife always comes up with    something I forgot to do.
Change of plans today, people.
I need to recalibrate the optronic    integrator on Level Five.
What is it, Rom?
I volunteer. I like phase-   shifting reconfigurations.
Thank you, but I'll do that    myself. I want the rest of you to    concentrate on the new inertial    coupling ports. I want all sixty-   four ports completed today.

Whatley -- you and Tekoa cover the    docking ring. Abdon and Nori, the    cargo bays. Rom -- the upper    pylons. Any questions?         Good. One more thing -- since I'm   working alone today, I'm going to    be very busy. Try not to    interrupt me with anything    unimportant. Is that clear?
Computer, locate Keiko O'Brien.
Keiko O'Brien is in her quarters.
Computer, initiate a full identity    scan on Keiko O'Brien and note    inconsistencies with any existing    medical records.
Scan complete. No inconsistencies    found. Identity confirmed.
How long would it take for a level    three stasis field to render Keiko    O'Brien unconscious?
All cognitive reflexes would cease    in two-point-one seconds.
Too long.        Calculate the time if anesthetine    gas were used.
One-point-four seconds.
What about a phaser set to stun?
Zero-point-nine seconds.
Damn it.
God help me...
There you are, Chief.        I was beginning to think you were    going to miss your own party.
Sorry I'm late.        Had to tie up a few loose ends.    Where's Keiko?
In the bedroom, helping Molly put    on different shoes -- a little    fashion crisis. But as usual,    your wife has handled everything.    You're a lucky man, Miles.
She's really outdone herself this    time.        Take it from an old cook --    Q'parol is a very time-consuming    dish to make.
Make a wish.
Happy birthday, sweetheart.
Single malt Irish whiskey. Neat.        Molly wanted to wear her new    purple shoes for you. Doesn't she    look pretty?
Very pretty.
All the food's out on the table,    dear, so just relax with our    friends.    (taking the tray of     drinks)    I'll pass these around.
I need to talk to you.
Not right now, Miles... we have    guests.
Sorry I'm late.
Dax! I was afraid you weren't    going to make it.
I heard you were serving Q'parol.    How could I stay away?
What's the matter, Chief? You    seem preoccupied. Is everything    all right?
It's nothing. I just forgot to    tell Keiko something... would you    excuse me for a moment?
Of course.
Did you meet any Pah-wraiths?
Pah-wraiths?
In the Fire Caves. Odo was    telling me the caves were haunted    by some sort of weird supernatural    beings.
Don't tell me you believe in    wraiths?
I may have mentioned the Bajoran    legends about creatures living in    the caves. But I never said I    believed them.
Well, the only thing I saw in the   caves were some very beautiful and   botanically fascinating fungi.
Well, maybe next time you go to   the Fire Caves, I could come   along.       I've always wanted to meet a Pah-   wraith.
Maybe you will. You never know...
I've done what you wanted.
That's terrific, Miles. You can   tell me all about it... later.
Can I have cake now?
In a bit, sweetie.
Miles -- are you bleeding?
No, I'm all right. It's nothing --
Let me look at that.
I said it's nothing.
I'm sorry. Sorry, everybody.
Excuse me...
Get a hold of yourself.
I've done what you wanted. Now    give me my wife back.
You've done well, Miles.
But recalibrating the optronic    integrator was only a test. I had    to be sure I could trust you.        Tomorrow, the real work begins.
Now it's time we got back to our    guests. We don't want to raise    any suspicions, do we?
Is Molly asleep?
Yes.
(showing him the empty     casserole)   The Q'parol was a big success.
No more games. No more tests.   Just tell me what you want done.
We'll talk about it in the   morning. It's late and you're   working a double shift tomorrow.
I want to talk about it now.
Miles -- I make the rules.       Now relax. Everything's going to   be fine as long as you do what I   ask.
Let's go to bed.
I'm sleeping on the couch.
Don't be childish. What if Molly    has one of her nightmares and    comes running in? You'll sleep    next to me, just like you always    do.
I'll be there in a minute.
Don't stay up too late. You've    got a busy day tomorrow.
Computer. I want to see a record    of all Bajoran legends concerning    the Pah-wraiths.
There are six thousand, four    hundred, twenty-seven entries in    the data banks that reference that    subject.  Please specify.
Miles...
Sleep well, Miles.
scene: 17   INT. O'BRIEN'S BEDROOM - OVERHEAD ON O'BRIEN

quote: Another weakness of you corporeal    lifeforms: your need for physical    intimacy.
It's especially irritating in your    young.
I've got to get Molly ready for    school.
I'll do it. You have a big day    ahead of you.
Molly's going to sleep at the    Davis's tonight, and she's staying    there until this is over.
Do you really think that's wise?        A little girl needs her mother.    Molly would be lost without hers.
You keep away from her.
Miles... I would never do anything    to hurt your daughter...        Unless you force me to.
These are your instructions.    Follow them precisely.
Recalibrating and sequencing the    impulse response filters in the    subspace communication    emitters... what's all that for?
We've gone over this, Miles. It's    not your concern.
Then how do I know this won't    jeopardize the station?
Because I've told you so. Now    stop asking me so many questions.    All it's doing is making me angry.        And you know who pays the price    for that, don't you?
I almost forgot -- here's your    birthday present.
Go ahead, open it. It's from your    wife.
There's an inscription on the    back.
Your wife cares about you very    much.
Computer, locate Captain Sisko.
Captain Sisko is in Security.
Miles!
I love you.
No!
Doctor Bashir to the Promenade!
You didn't see anyone near her    before she fell?
Nobody. But I was passing under    the walkway and my back was to    her.
(curious, not     accusatory)    What were you doing on the    Promenade?
What?
Weren't you supposed to be working    on some optronic circuitry on    Level Five?
I was going to the Replimat... for    lunch.
Keiko's going to be all right.    She's lucky she landed the way she    did. It distributed the impact.    A fall from that height could    easily have killed her, or left    her paralyzed.
Is she conscious?
Yes, but she's still in shock.    She has a broken femur and a    hairline fracture of the right    parietal bone.
Can I see her?
Maybe in a couple of hours. She    needs rest.
Julian -- I have to see her now.
Doctor.
All right -- but only for a few    minutes. Don't excite her.
Keiko?
You were going to tell them about    me.
How did you know?
I know everything your wife knows --   and she knows you.        I told you we have to trust one    another. You violated that trust,    and look where it's led us.
I want my wife back, do you hear    me? I want her back.
Then stop trying to fool me. How    much more damage do you think this    body can take?
Now, no more tricks. Agreed?
Say it.
Agreed.
Good.        You know what you need to do. You    should get back to work.
I'll have everything completed in    thirty-six hours.
You have thirteen -- and not a    minute more.
I can't do it that fast.
You're a very resourceful man   You'll find a way...       For Keiko's sake.
You bloody --
She needs to rest.
Tell Molly I'll be home soon.   Tell her Mommy is fine. Don't   scare her.
Miles... give me a kiss.
I'm counting on you.
She'll be back on her feet soon.   I promise.
Computer. Begin a thirteen hour    countdown. Now.
Clock activated.
Chief.
I heard about Mrs. O'Brien's    accident. How is she?
Julian says she'll be home soon.
That's good. Is there anything I    can do to help?
I wish there was, Worf. I really    do.        I've got to go -- I'm falling    behind schedule.
Computer, time?
Eight hours, twenty-two minutes    and three seconds remain.
Chief.
Sorry -- I didn't mean to startle    you.
What are you doing here?
Reporting for my next assignment.    I've completed calibration tests    on the inertial coupling ports on    all three upper pylons.
Already?
How'd you finish so quickly?

I just did the work. I didn't    allow myself to get caught up in    any of the distracting discussions    the other workers engage in.    Ferengi can be very focused.    Especially when no one bothers to    talk to them.
I see.
Not that I mind. I'm used to    being ignored.
Is something wrong, Chief?        I can work slower if you want me    to...
Rom... I need your help, and I    need you to keep your mouth shut.    Can I count on you?
Is that a trick question?
Rom -- this is serious.
You can depend on me, Chief.
We're going to make some    modifications to several of the    station's systems. You're not to    breathe one word about this to    anyone. That includes Dax, Odo,    Captain Sisko, Worf...
They don't know?
Of course they know. Some of    them, anyway. But they have to    pretend they don't. This is a top    secret Starfleet operation.
Culpable deniability. I    understand. Don't worry about me,    Chief. My lips are sealed.    Nobody will get anything out of    me. Not even my name.
Rom, everybody on the station    knows your name.
Right.        But I won't confirm it. Where do    we start?
I hope you feel rested, because    you won't be getting any sleep    tonight.
First, I want you to complete this   com relay bypass...
Computer, time remaining?
Six hours, forty-one minutes,    twenty-six seconds.
Commander, what are you doing up    at this hour?
I want you to look at something.
I couldn't sleep so I got up and    decided to scan the wormhole for    radiometric anomalies.
At three in the morning?
I find anomalies very relaxing.    I was using the wideband filter    protocols and when I ran the    primary calibration check I found    this --
They're slightly off spec.
Yes. I thought it might be a    fused matrix inverter, until I ran    a level three diagnostic.        Have a look.
We'd better wake the captain.       We have a saboteur on the station.
All right, what have you got?
Computer, display diagnostic.
Chief...
We've identified nine hundred and    forty-three tiny fluctuations in    the primary communication relays    and several power distribution    junctions.
"Fluctuations" that can't be    attributed to anything except    external intervention.
Someone's gained access to our    systems and is altering them.         For what purpose?
We're working on that. At this    point, it's hard to even call it    sabotage -- there's been no real    damage...
... the systems are just slightly   off spec.        So far, none of these alterations    appear to pose a threat to the    station.
So far. But this might be just    the tip of a very large and    dangerous iceberg.
Is there any way to trace how this    was done, and by whom?
It has to be someone familiar with    the station's systems.
Maybe someone who worked on the    station under the Cardassians...
I'm running extensive security    checks on all recent visitors, but    so far, I haven't found anything.
It could be someone who's been on    the station a long time... someone    with a lot of access... maybe even    someone on the maintenance crew.
Chief?
Yes.
Yes, what? You think it's someone    on your staff?
Chief O'Brien, I have a call from    your daughter.
Go ahead, Chief.
Molly, honey, what is it?
Hi, Daddy. Mommy told me I could    call you.
I hope we're not interrupting    anything important.
It's all right, Molly. I'm glad    you called. What are you doing    home?
She missed her mommy. Isn't that    sweet?
When are you going to come --
Oww! Mommy, that hurt.
I'm sorry.
Are you all right, sweetie?
She's fine, Miles. She wants to    know when you'll be finished.        I told her you had to work for    another two hours and twenty-two    minutes and thirteen seconds.
How long is that, Daddy?
I'll be home soon, sweetie. Very    soon.
Good.       We both miss you.
Everything all right?
Fine.  Sorry about the   interruption.
You were saying you thought you   knew who the saboteur might be...
I think I have an idea...
Hello, Constable. Hello, Chief.
What are you doing, Rom?
I-I can't talk about it.
Oh, yes you can. And you will.
I'll take care of those.
Coming, Chief?
I'd better see what he's been up    to here.
Has he said anything?
Not much. For the first forty    minutes, it was like pulling teeth    even getting him to admit his    name.
You think he's working alone?
I don't know. Rom admits to    nothing. And now he's asking for    Chief O'Brien. He won't talk to    anybody else.
Then get the chief down here. I    want to know what's going on.
Security to Chief O'Brien.
Go ahead, Constable.
We need you in Security right    away.
I'm still trying to figure out    what Rom did to these systems.
That will have to wait. I have    captain's orders to get you down    here -- immediately.
On my way.
Computer, time remaining?
Thirty-six minutes and nine    seconds.
Computer, locate maintenance    technician Rom.
Maintenance technician Rom is in    Security holding cell number four.
Initiate security override and    scramble Surveillance Channels    Four A, B, C and D. Authorization    O'Brien seven-one-two.
Specified security channels    scrambled.
Now begin recalibration of    gravitic sensors at Access Panel    Three Nine Seven as indicated.    I'll return in ten minutes.
The chief is here, Rom. Now what    do you have to say?
Alone. I'll only talk if we're    alone.
What is it, Rom?
It's all right. I disconnected    Odo's eavesdropping devices.
I haven't told anyone anything,    just like you said.
You're a good man. Now why'd you    call for me? I told you we were    under very tight time constraints.
Captain Sisko is really angry. If   I didn't know he was pretending...
Rom...
Don't worry, I can hold out until    you say otherwise, but there is    one thing I have to know...
Go ahead.
Why are we focusing a chroniton    beam at the wormhole?
What?

The new frequency of the deflector    grid is set to turn the station    into a massive chroniton array    aimed directly at the wormhole.    So I just want to know -- why are    we trying to kill the wormhole    aliens?
What are you talking about? A    chroniton beam is harmless.
To us -- but its temporal    disruption would kill a wormhole    alien instantly.
Of course, why didn't I think of    that.        She's had me so on edge I couldn't    see the forest for the trees.
Who's "she?"
Look, I don't have time to    explain. The question is why    would anyone want to kill the    wormhole aliens?
Everyone has enemies, even the    Prophets.

That's right... they're not just    wormhole aliens... they're    Prophets. They're part of Bajoran    mythology...    (everything is beginning     to fall into place)   ... just like the Pah-wraiths that    live in the Fire Caves. So the    question is... what do these    wraiths have to do with the    wormhole aliens?
Koss'moran.
What?

It's a Bajoran legend. From the    verb kosst, meaning "to be" and    amoran -- "banished".        Leeta's been telling me all about    Bajoran legends. She can go on    for hours.        She says I'm a good listener...
I'm sure you are -- but now's the    time to be a good talker. Go on.
Well... according to Leeta, the    Pah-wraiths used to live in the    wormhole. They were part of the    Celestial Temple.
They were Prophets?

False Prophets... They were cast    out of the Temple. Exiled to the    caves, they were imprisoned in    crystal fire cages and forbidden    to ever return "lest they face the    Wrath of the True Prophets."
So if a False Prophet tried to    return to the Celestial Temple...
I don't think they'd be welcomed.
Unless she kills all the wormhole    aliens first...        Rom -- I'm going to have to leave    you in a tough spot.
Captain Sisko... Odo... they don't    know about any of this, do they?
No, Rom. They don't. And you    have to help me keep it that way    for a little while longer.
I have to stay here and play the    idiot?
I'm afraid so. Whatever Odo asks    you --
I'm Quark's brother. I know the    role.
Computer, time remaining?
Twelve minutes, twenty-two    seconds.
Sorry to disturb you, Chief. But    a couple of things are still   bothering me. Rom couldn't have    done all this sabotage alone.    There were too many changes for    any one person to make.
(keeping focused on his    task)   Maybe so, but right now I've got   a frequency problem in the cascade   feeder...
I checked with the repair logs...    I was hoping to match someone's    movements to the locations where    the alterations were made.
But I couldn't do that.
We had a matrix system failure    yesterday and those records were    lost. Sorry.
We've had a lot of system failures    recently, haven't we, Chief?
I hadn't noticed. I've been busy    repairing things.
Like the surveillance channels in    the holding cells? You authorized    a security override. What was    wrong with them?
The fiber optic relays were out of    sync. The isolinear chip junction    was --
Enough, Chief.
You didn't cover your tracks very    well. Why?
I didn't have time.        I still don't.
Sorry, Odo.        Chief O'Brien to Keiko O'Brien.
This is Keiko.
I'm finished, but we've got to    move quickly.    (looking at the fallen     Odo)    This place is going to be swarming    with security -- meet me at    Runabout Pad "C." Now.
How did you know I'd want a    runabout?

Because I know what you're    planning to do. But don't worry,    I don't give a damn about the    Celestial Temple, or your non-   corporeal feuds. I just want my    wife back. Now you still need me    to pilot you to the wormhole so    let's stop wasting time. Agreed?
I'll meet you there.
That's correct, Commander. I want    to test some new magnetic    constrictors on the runabout's    impulse thrusters.
Very well, Chief. You're cleared    for departure, but before you go,    there's one thing I'd like to ask    you.
What's that?
Did you enjoy your birthday?
It was full of surprises.
Hold position here.
Computer. Initiate modifications    O'Brien seven-three-one and enable    remote com-link.
Com-link enabled.
What the hell --
Target the center of the wormhole.
Target coordinates, set.
Have us face the Temple. The   blast will only last a fraction of   a second...       They'll all be dead before they   even see it.
You have no idea how many   centuries I've waited for this...
Let's get on with it.
You have a lot to learn about    patience, Miles.
Proceed.
Chief -- what's going on out    there?
I'm ordering you to return to the    station -- now!
Activate.
Keiko!
Miles?
You have some explaining to do,    Chief.

It was more like having something    coiled around inside my head. I    could see and hear through it, but    every time I tried to do anything,    it was like...       ... like being stuck in sand, then    squeezed.
Could you sense any of its    thoughts?
Just feelings, sometimes. Kind of    a cold rage.        I don't think it ever had any    intention of leaving either one of    us alive.
You don't have to talk about it if    you don't want to.
It feels good to talk about it.   Besides...    (looks fondly at     O'Brien)   I'll never forget how hard you    fought for me.
Hello, brother.
You look horrible. I'm telling    you, Rom -- working the night    shift is driving you to an early    grave.
I wasn't working.
What do you mean you weren't    working?
I'm not on the night shift    anymore.
I knew it. O'Brien fired you.
No, Brother. In appreciation of    my work the chief has promoted me    to the day shift... he says I have    a promising future in Engineering.
Then why do you look so tired?
I was out celebrating.
With who?
My crewmates.
I think they like me.
Do they?
Especially Litana, she's always    finding excuses to talk to me.
Well, I'm glad things are going so    well for you, Rom.
No, you're not. But thanks    anyway, brother.
So I suppose you'll be wanting -   the "Chief's Special" again?
Actually, no. I've discovered    bacon doesn't agree with me.
What a surprise.
Instead, I'll have a short stack    of pancakes, dripping with butter,    side of sausage and pineapple.
Pineapple?
That's the breakfast of choice on    the day shift.
Pineapple.
